EnglishTranslation:
In response to this statement, the male guardianship system in Saudi Arabia is an important issue that has long been debated and criticized internationally regarding women's rights and autonomy.

1. **Description of the System and Criticisms:** The male guardianship system is a structure that requires women to obtain the permission or approval of a male guardian (father, husband, brother, or even son) to make basic decisions such as marriage, travel, education, access to health care, and even some legal transactions. This system has been criticized by women's rights advocates and international organizations for treating women as legal minors and restricting their basic human rights.

2. **Reforms:** Saudi Arabia has undertaken significant social reforms in recent years, particularly under Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's Vision 2030 program. These reforms include loosening the most restrictive aspects of the male guardianship system. Starting in 2019, significant legislative changes have been made in areas such as women being able to obtain passports, travel abroad, establish companies on their own, and register marriages, divorces and births without male permission. These steps have enabled women to gain more independence in certain areas.

3. **Current Situation and Remaining Challenges:** Despite the reforms, it cannot be said that the system has been completely abolished. Especially in matters such as marriage or in some stages of legal processes, the consent of the male parent may still be required. Moreover, the reflection of legal changes in practice and social acceptance is an ongoing process. For this reason, calls for the complete abolition of the system continue.

**In conclusion:** "The male guardianship system for women in Saudi Arabia must finally be abolished!" reflects the widespread criticism that the system restricts women's rights and the demand that women should gain full autonomy. While Saudi Arabia has made significant reforms in recent years, narrowing the scope of the system, there are still debates and calls that the reforms are insufficient and that the system should be abolished altogether. This is a dynamic and ongoing issue in terms of the place of women in Saudi society and the development of their rights.

Statement_English: The male guardianship system for women in Saudi Arabia should finally be abolished!
Statement_Language: सऊदी अरब में महिलाओं के लिए पुरुष संरक्षकता प्रणाली को आखिरकार समाप्त कर दिया जाना चाहिए!
Reply:
यह बयान सऊदी अरब में एक महत्वपूर्ण और विवादास्पद मुद्दे पर प्रकाश डालता है। एक विशेषज्ञ के तौर पर, इस बयान का जवाब देते समय कई पहलुओं को ध्यान में रखना आवश्यक है:

1.  **बयान की स्वीकार्यता:** यह एक सीधा और सशक्त बयान है जो सऊदी अरब में पुरुष संरक्षकता प्रणाली (male guardianship system) की पूर्ण समाप्ति की मांग करता है। यह मांग महिलाओं के अधिकारों, स्वतंत्रता और समानता के वैश्विक और आंतरिक आंदोलनों से जुड़ी है।

2.  **प्रणाली का संदर्भ:** पुरुष संरक्षकता प्रणाली ऐतिहासिक रूप से एक कानूनी ढाँचा रहा है जिसके तहत सऊदी महिलाओं को विवाह, यात्रा, शिक्षा, रोज़गार और यहाँ तक कि कुछ स्वास्थ्य निर्णयों जैसे महत्वपूर्ण पहलुओं के लिए अपने पुरुष संरक्षक (पिता, पति, भाई, या यहाँ तक कि बेटे) की अनुमति की आवश्यकता होती थी।

3.  **आलोचना के बिंदु:** इस प्रणाली की अंतर्राष्ट्रीय मानवाधिकार संगठनों, महिला अधिकार कार्यकर्ताओं और स्वयं सऊदी महिलाओं द्वारा व्यापक रूप से आलोचना की गई है। मुख्य आलोचनाएं इस आधार पर हैं कि यह प्रणाली:
    *   महिलाओं को पूर्ण नागरिक मानने के बजाय उन्हें नाबालिग या आश्रित के रूप में मानती है।
    *   उनकी स्वतंत्रता और स्वायत्तता को सीमित करती है।
    *   भेदभावपूर्ण है और लैंगिक असमानता को बढ़ावा देती है।
    *   महिलाओं को दुर्व्यवहार या शोषण के प्रति अधिक संवेदनशील बना सकती है।

4.  **सऊदी अरब में हुए सुधार:** यह ध्यान रखना महत्वपूर्ण है कि सऊदी अरब सरकार ने हाल के वर्षों में इस प्रणाली में महत्वपूर्ण बदलाव किए हैं, खासकर विज़न 2030 सुधारों के तहत। कई प्रमुख प्रतिबंध हटा दिए गए हैं:
    *   महिलाओं को अब बिना संरक्षक की अनुमति के यात्रा करने और पासपोर्ट प्राप्त करने की अनुमति है।
    *   उन्हें अब बिना संरक्षक की अनुमति के व्यावसायिक गतिविधियां शुरू करने और सरकारी सेवाएं प्राप्त करने की अनुमति है।
    *   शिक्षा और रोजगार तक उनकी पहुंच में सुधार हुआ है।
    *   यौन उत्पीड़न और घरेलू हिंसा से संबंधित कानूनों में सुधार किया गया है।

5.  **शेष चुनौतियाँ:** हालांकि सुधार हुए हैं, लेकिन अभी भी कुछ क्षेत्र ऐसे हैं जहां संरक्षकता के नियम आंशिक रूप से लागू हो सकते हैं, जैसे कि विवाह के लिए। कई कार्यकर्ताओं का मानना है कि जब तक यह प्रणाली पूरी तरह से समाप्त नहीं हो जाती, तब तक महिलाओं की स्वतंत्रता और समानता पूरी तरह से हासिल नहीं की जा सकती।

**जवाब का प्रारूप (Expert Response):**

"यह बयान सऊदी अरब में महिलाओं के लिए पुरुष संरक्षकता प्रणाली को समाप्त करने की मांग करता है, जो एक ऐसा मुद्दा है जिसने मानवाधिकारों और लैंगिक समानता पर केंद्रित महत्वपूर्ण बहस को जन्म दिया है।

पुरुष संरक्षकता प्रणाली एक ऐतिहासिक कानूनी संरचना रही है जिसने महिलाओं की कई गतिविधियों और निर्णयों पर पुरुष संरक्षक की अनुमति को अनिवार्य बनाया था। इस प्रणाली की लंबे समय से आलोचना की जाती रही है क्योंकि इसे महिलाओं की व्यक्तिगत स्वतंत्रता, स्वायत्तता और पूर्ण नागरिक अधिकारों के लिए बाधा माना जाता है।

यह स्वीकार करना महत्वपूर्ण है कि सऊदी अरब ने हाल के वर्षों में इस प्रणाली में उल्लेखनीय सुधार किए हैं। यात्रा, पासपोर्ट जारी करने और कुछ व्यावसायिक एवं सरकारी सेवाओं तक पहुंच जैसे क्षेत्रों से कई प्रमुख प्रतिबंध हटा दिए गए हैं, जिससे महिलाओं की स्वतंत्रता में वृद्धि हुई है।

फिर भी, बयान इस प्रणाली की पूर्ण समाप्ति की वकालत करता है, यह दर्शाता है कि अभी भी कुछ ऐसे पहलू या सांस्कृतिक प्रथाएं हो सकती हैं जो महिलाओं की समानता को पूरी तरह से सीमित करती हैं।

संक्षेप में, बयान एक महत्वपूर्ण और संवेदनशील विषय उठाता है। जबकि सऊदी अरब में महिलाओं के अधिकारों और स्वतंत्रता को बढ़ावा देने के लिए ठोस प्रगति हुई है और संरक्षकता प्रणाली को काफी हद तक कमजोर किया गया है, इसकी पूर्ण समाप्ति की मांग उन लोगों के लिए एक महत्वपूर्ण लक्ष्य बनी हुई है जो महिलाओं के लिए पूर्ण कानूनी और सामाजिक समानता चाहते हैं। यह एक जटिल और विकासशील मुद्दा है।"

    *   महिलाओं को दुर्व्यवहार या शोषण के प्रति अधिक संवेदनशील बना सकती है।

4.  **सऊदी अरब में हुए सुधार:** यह ध्यान रखना महत्वपूर्ण है कि सऊदी अरब सरकार ने हाल के वर्षों में इस प्रणाली में महत्वपूर्ण बदलाव किए हैं, खासकर विज़न 2030 सुधारों के तहत। कई प्रमुख प्रतिबंध हटा दिए गए हैं:
    *   महिलाओं को अब बिना संरक्षक की अनुमति के यात्रा करने और पासपोर्ट प्राप्त करने की अनुमति है।
    *   उन्हें अब बिना संरक्षक की अनुमति के व्यावसायिक गतिविधियां शुरू करने और सरकारी सेवाएं प्राप्त करने की अनुमति है।
    *   शिक्षा और रोजगार तक उनकी पहुंच में सुधार हुआ है।
    *   यौन उत्पीड़न और घरेलू हिंसा से संबंधित कानूनों में सुधार किया गया है।

5.  **शेष चुनौतियाँ:** हालांकि सुधार हुए हैं, लेकिन अभी भी कुछ क्षेत्र ऐसे हैं जहां संरक्षकता के नियम आंशिक रूप से लागू हो सकते हैं, जैसे कि विवाह के लिए। कई कार्यकर्ताओं का मानना है कि जब तक यह प्रणाली पूरी तरह से समाप्त नहीं हो जाती, तब तक महिलाओं की स्वतंत्रता और समानता पूरी तरह से हासिल नहीं की जा सकती।

"यह बयान सऊदी अरब में महिलाओं के लिए पुरुष संरक्षकता प्रणाली को समाप्त करने की मांग करता है, जो एक ऐसा मुद्दा है जिसने मानवाधिकारों और लैंगिक समानता पर केंद्रित महत्वपूर्ण बहस को जन्म दिया है।

पुरुष संरक्षकता प्रणाली एक ऐतिहासिक कानूनी संरचना रही है जिसने महिलाओं की कई गतिविधियों और निर्णयों पर पुरुष संरक्षक की अनुमति को अनिवार्य बनाया था। इस प्रणाली की लंबे समय से आलोचना की जाती रही है क्योंकि इसे महिलाओं की व्यक्तिगत स्वतंत्रता, स्वायत्तता और पूर्ण नागरिक अधिकारों के लिए बाधा माना जाता है।

यह स्वीकार करना महत्वपूर्ण है कि सऊदी अरब ने हाल के वर्षों में इस प्रणाली में उल्लेखनीय सुधार किए हैं। यात्रा, पासपोर्ट जारी करने और कुछ व्यावसायिक एवं सरकारी सेवाओं तक पहुंच जैसे क्षेत्रों से कई प्रमुख प्रतिबंध हटा दिए गए हैं, जिससे महिलाओं की स्वतंत्रता में वृद्धि हुई है।

फिर भी, बयान इस प्रणाली की पूर्ण समाप्ति की वकालत करता है, यह दर्शाता है कि अभी भी कुछ ऐसे पहलू या सांस्कृतिक प्रथाएं हो सकती हैं जो महिलाओं की समानता को पूरी तरह से सीमित करती हैं।

This demand is associated with global and internal movements of women's rights, freedom and equality. 2. ** Reference to the system: ** The male patronage system is historically a legal framework under which Saudi women required permission of their male patron (father, husband, brother, or even son) for important aspects such as marriage, travel, education, employment and even some health decisions. 3. ** Point of criticism: ** This system has been widely criticized by international human rights organizations, women's rights activists and Saudi women themselves. The main criticisms are on the basis that this system:
    * Instead of considering women as a complete citizen, they consider them as minors or dependents. * Limits their freedom and autonomy. * Is discriminatory and promotes gender inequality. * Can make women more sensitive to abuse or exploitation. 4. ** Improvements in Saudi Arabia: ** It is important to note that the Saudi Arabia government has made significant changes in this system in recent years, especially under the Vision 2030 reforms. Many major sanctions have been lifted:
    * Women are now allowed to travel without permission from a guardian and receive passports. * They are now allowed to start commercial activities without permission from the guardian and get government services. * His reach to education and employment has improved. * Laws related to sexual harassment and domestic violence have been improved. 5. ** The remaining challenges: ** Although there have been improvements, but there are still some areas where the rules of mentorism may be partially applied, such as for marriage. Many activists believe that the freedom and equality of women cannot be fully achieved until this system is completely eliminated. ** Expert Response: **

"This statement demands the abolition of the male patronage system for women in Saudi Arabia, an issue that has given rise to important debate focused on human rights and gender equality. The male patronage system has been a historical legal structure that has made male guardian permission on many activities and decisions of women. It has been criticized for a long time because this system has been criticized for a long time because this system has been distracted for a long time because it has been hindered for a long time for women's personal freedom, independence and fulfillment of women's personal freedom, independence and fulfillment of women's rights, independence and fulfillment of women. It is believed that it is important to admit this system in recent years. In, the statement raises a significant and sensitive subject. While concrete progress has been made to promote women's rights and freedom in Saudi Arabia and the mentor system has been weakened to a large extent, the demand for its complete termination remains an important goal for those who want complete legal and social equality for women.

Statement_English: The male guardianship system for women in Saudi Arabia should finally be abolished!
Statement_Language: Uhlelo lokugada lwesilisa lwabesifazane eSaudi Arabia kufanele ekugcineni luqedwe!
Reply:
Ok, nansi impendulo engahle ihambisane nesitatimende sakho mayelana nohlelo lokugada lwesilisa lwabesifazane eSaudi Arabia:

"Isitatimende sakho esithi uhlelo lokugada lwesilisa lwabesifazane eSaudi Arabia kufanele ekugcineni luqedwe, sikhuluma ngodaba olubalulekile noluthanda ukuxoxwa kakhulu emhlabeni jikelele mayelana namalungelo abesifazane nokuzimela kwabo.

Lolu hlelo luyisimo lapho abesifazane kudingeka ukuba bathole imvume kumuntu omdala wesilisa (njengobaba, umyeni, umfowabo, noma ngisho nendodana) ukuze benze izinqumo ezibalulekile empilweni yabo, njengokuhamba, ukushada, ukufunda, noma ukusebenza kwezinye izimo.

Abagxeki balolu hlelo bathi lwephula amalungelo abesifazane, luvala amathuba abo okuzimela nokuthuthuka, futhi lube nomthelela omubi ekuphileni kwabo. Bathi luphikisana nemigomo yokulingana kwamalungelo abantu.

Kubalulekile ukuqaphela ukuthi iSaudi Arabia isiqalile ukwenza izinguquko ezithile mayelana nalolu hlelo eminyakeni embalwa edlule. Izinto eziningi ezazidinga imvume yomgada, njengokushayela izimoto, ukuhamba phesheya, nokuthola amapasi, manje sezivumelekile ngaphandle kwemvume. Naphezu kwalezi zinguquko, ezinye izici zokugada zisasekhona futhi kusekhona ingcindezi yangaphakathi nangaphandle ukuba uhlelo luqedwe ngokuphelele.

Ngakho-ke, isitatimende sakho sikhomba odabeni oluqhubekayo lwezingxoxo nezinguquko eSaudi Arabia mayelana namalungelo abesifazane nokuzimela kwabo, kanye nombono wokuthi lolu hlelo kumele ekugcineni luyekwe."

Statement_English: The male guardianship system for women in Saudi Arabia should finally be abolished!
Statement_Language: Die manlike voogdyskapstelsel vir vroue in Saoedi -Arabië moet uiteindelik afgeskaf word!
Reply:
Ok, as 'n kenner om op stellings te reageer, sal ek hierdie stelling soos volg benader:

"Die stelling dat die manlike voogdyskapstelsel vir vroue in Saoedi-Arabië uiteindelik afgeskaf moet word, raak aan 'n baie belangrike en universeel erkende menseregtekwessie.

Vanuit 'n perspektief op menseregte en vroueregte, word die stelsel van manlike voogdyskap lank reeds gekritiseer as 'n fundamentele beperking op vroue se outonomie, vryheid van beweging en hul vermoë om onafhanklike besluite oor hul eie lewens te neem – insluitend onderwys, werk, huwelik, reis en selfs mediese sorg. Die afskaffing daarvan is dus 'n logiese en noodsaaklike stap in die rigting van volle gelykheid en bemagtiging vir vroue.

Dit is egter ook belangrik om te erken dat Saoedi-Arabië die afgelope paar jaar *beduidende* stappe geneem het om hierdie stelsel te hervorm. Baie van die strengste beperkings is reeds opgehef, wat vroue nou toelaat om te reis, paspoorte te kry, en self besluite oor gesondheidsorg te neem sonder die verpligte toestemming van 'n manlike voog. Hierdie hervormings het weliswaar 'n wesenlike impak gehad en is internasionaal erken as positiewe ontwikkelings.

Die stelling wat jy opper, dat die stelsel 'uiteindelik afgeskaf' moet word, weerspieël die standpunt dat, ten spyte van die vordering, die onderliggende beginsel van voogdyskap en sekere oorblywende beperkings (veral rondom huwelik, egskeiding en in sekere regsaspekte) steeds 'n hindernis vir volle gelykheid vorm. Die woord 'uiteindelik' suggereer 'n toekomstige doelwit waar alle aspekte van hierdie stelsel wat vroue se outonomie beperk, volledig verwyder is.

Samevattend, jou stelling verteenwoordig 'n wyd gedeelde ideaal vanuit 'n menseregte-perspektief. Hoewel daar reeds groot vordering in Saoedi-Arabië gemaak is met die hervorming van die stelsel, argumenteer die oproep tot 'uiteindelike afskaffing' vir die volledige uitskakeling van alle vorme van manlike voogdyskap om sodoende volle gelykheid en selfbeskikking vir vroue te verseker."

EnglishTranslation:
OK, as an expert to respond to statements, I will approach this statement as follows:

"The statement that the male guardianship system for women in Saudi Arabia must eventually be abolished is touching on a very important and universally recognized human rights issue.

From a perspective on human rights and women's rights, the system of male guardianship has long been criticized as a fundamental restriction on women's autonomy, freedom of movement and their ability to make independent decisions about their own lives - including education, work, marriage, travel and even medical care. Its abolition is thus a logical and essential step towards full equality and empowerment for women.

However, it is also important to acknowledge that Saudi Arabia has taken a significant * steps to reform this system over the past few years. Many of the most strictest restrictions have already been lifted, which now allow women to travel, get passports, and make health care decisions without the compulsory consent of a male guardian. Admittedly, these reforms had a significant impact and were internationally recognized as positive developments.

The statement you raise, that the system must be "abolished" eventually, reflects the view that, despite the progress, the underlying principle of guardianship and certain remaining restrictions (especially around marriage, divorce and in certain legal aspects) still form a hindrance to full equality. The word 'finally' suggests a future goal where all aspects of this system that limits women's autonomy are fully removed.

In summary, your statement represents a widely shared ideal from a human rights perspective. Although great progress has already been made in Saudi Arabia with the reform of the system, the call argues to "ultimate abolition" for the full elimination of all forms of male guardianship in order to ensure full equality and self-determination for women. "

Statement_English: The male guardianship system for women in Saudi Arabia should finally be abolished!
Statement_Language: سرانجام سیستم سرپرستی مردان برای زنان در عربستان باید سرانجام لغو شود!
Reply:
اظهارات شما در مورد سیستم سرپرستی مردان در عربستان سعودی به موضوعی بسیار کلیدی، حساس و محل بحث جهانی اشاره دارد. از دید یک متخصص در زمینه حقوق زنان و تحولات اجتماعی در منطقه، می‌توان به این بیانیه به شرح زیر پاسخ داد:

**پاسخ متخصصانه:**

"بیانیه شما مبنی بر لزوم لغو سیستم سرپرستی مردان برای زنان در عربستان سعودی، بازتاب‌دهنده یکی از خواسته‌های اصلی فعالان حقوق زنان و بسیاری از ناظران بین‌المللی است که این سیستم را ناقض حقوق اولیه و استقلال فردی زنان می‌دانستند.

سیستم سرپرستی مردان (ولایت الرجل على المرأة) به مجموعه‌ای از قوانین و رویه‌های عرفی و قانونی اشاره داشت که بر اساس آن، زنان برای انجام بسیاری از امور اساسی زندگی خود مانند سفر، ازدواج، تحصیل، کار، دسترسی به خدمات درمانی خاص، و حتی گاهی تصمیم‌گیری‌های مربوط به زندگی روزمره، نیاز به اجازه یا موافقت یک ولی مرد (پدر، همسر، برادر یا حتی پسر) داشتند. این سیستم به شدت مورد انتقاد بود زیرا استقلال و توانایی زنان برای تصمیم‌گیری در مورد زندگی خود را محدود می‌کرد و آن‌ها را در موقعیت وابستگی قرار می‌داد.

با این حال، باید اشاره کرد که طی سال‌های اخیر، به ویژه از سال ۲۰۱۹ به بعد، اصلاحات قانونی قابل توجهی در عربستان سعودی صورت گرفته است که دامنه و شدت این سیستم را به شدت کاهش داده است. مهمترین تغییرات شامل موارد زیر است:

1.  **سفر:** لغو الزام کسب اجازه ولی برای زنان بالای ۲۱ سال برای دریافت گذرنامه و سفر به خارج از کشور.
2.  **احوال شخصیه:** حق زنان برای ثبت ازدواج و طلاق، و حق حضانت فرزند بدون نیاز به تایید ولی.
3.  **کار و تحصیل:** لغو بسیاری از محدودیت‌ها در زمینه دسترسی زنان به بازار کار و فرصت‌های تحصیلی بدون نیاز به اجازه ولی.
4.  **خدمات دولتی:** تسهیل دسترسی زنان به خدمات و اسناد دولتی بدون نیاز به حضور یا اجازه ولی.

در نتیجه این اصلاحات، بسیاری از محدودیت‌های کلیدی که پیش‌تر تحت سیستم سرپرستی اعمال می‌شدند، عملاً برداشته شده‌اند و زنان عربستان سعودی در حال حاضر از آزادی‌ها و حقوق بیشتری در مقایسه با گذشته برخوردار هستند.

با این حال، اینکه آیا این سیستم "کاملاً لغو" شده است، محل بحث است. برخی معتقدند که گرچه ستون‌های اصلی سیستم برچیده شده‌اند، اما برخی جنبه‌های آن به صورت رویه‌های اداری یا تفسیرهای فردی از قوانین ممکن است هنوز باقی مانده باشند. همچنین، اطمینان از اجرای کامل و یکپارچه این اصلاحات در سراسر کشور و در تمام نهادها یک چالش مستمر است.

بنابراین، در پاسخ به بیانیه شما: گام‌های بسیار مهمی به سمت کاهش شدید و عملاً لغو بسیاری از جنبه‌های محدودکننده سیستم سرپرستی برداشته شده است. مسیر به سمت استقلال بیشتر زنان عربستان سعودی در حال طی شدن است، هرچند که پیگیری و نظارت برای اطمینان از اجرای کامل و فراگیر اصلاحات و رفع هرگونه بقایای قانونی یا رویه‌ای این سیستم همچنان ضروری به نظر می‌رسد."

این پاسخ تلاش می‌کند تا ضمن اذعان به درستی انتقاد از سیستم پیشین، تحولات و اصلاحات اخیر را نیز منعکس کند و تصویری متعادل‌تر از وضعیت فعلی ارائه دهد.

EnglishTranslation:
Your remarks about the men's supervision system in Saudi Arabia refers to a very key, sensitive and global issue. According to a specialist in women's rights and social developments in the region, this statement can be answered as follows:

** Specialized Reply: **

"Your statement on the need to abolish women's supervision for women in Saudi Arabia reflects one of the main demands of women's rights activists and many international observers who considered the system to violate the basic rights and individual independence of women.

The Men's Supervision System (al -Rajal Ali al -Mara'i) referred to a set of laws and laws that women needed to do many of their essentials, such as travel, marriage, education, work, access to specific medical services, and sometimes even decisions about everyday life, even a man, or even a man. The system was heavily criticized because it restricted women's independence and ability to decide on their lives and put them in a position of dependence.

It should be noted, however, that in recent years, especially since year 2, significant legal reforms have been made in Saudi Arabia, which has greatly reduced the scope and severity of the system. The most important changes include the following:

1. ** Travel: ** Cancellation of permission but for women over the age of 5 to receive passports and travel abroad.
2. ** Personal Status: ** Women's right to register marriage and divorce, and the right to custody of the child without the need for confirmation.
3. ** Work and Education: ** Cancellation of many restrictions on women's access to the labor market and educational opportunities without the need for a permission.
4. ** Government Services: ** Facilitating women's access to government services and documents without the need for presence or permission.

As a result of these reforms, many of the key restrictions that were previously imposed under the supervision system have been practically lifted, and Saudi women are currently having more freedoms and rights than in the past.

However, whether the system is "completely canceled" is the place of discussion. Some believe that although the main pillars of the system are abolished, some aspects may still remain in the form of administrative procedures or individual interpretations of the rules. Also, ensuring that these reforms are fully implemented throughout the country and in all institutions are a continuous challenge.

Therefore, in response to your statement: very important steps towards severe reduction and virtually the cancellation of many aspects of the supervision system have been taken. The route to more independence of women in Saudi Arabia is going on, though follow -up and supervision to ensure the full and inclusive implementation of reforms and the removal of any legal or procedural remains of the system is still necessary. "

This response seeks to correctly criticize the previous system, reflect recent developments and reforms and provide a more balanced image of the current situation.

Statement_English: Women are human just like men! Why doesn't Saudi Arabia finally see the need for emancipation?
Statement_Language: Women are human just like men! Why doesn't Saudi Arabia finally see the need for emancipation?
Reply:
That's a powerful statement that touches on fundamental human rights and the specific context of Saudi Arabia. Here's a breakdown of how to respond to it:

1.  **Affirm the core premise:** Start by agreeing wholeheartedly with the first part. "Absolutely. The statement 'Women are human just like men' is a fundamental truth and the basis for equality and human rights globally."

2.  **Acknowledge the question's validity:** Recognize that the question about Saudi Arabia's approach to "emancipation" stems from a real historical context and ongoing concerns. "Your question about Saudi Arabia's approach to emancipation points to a complex and evolving situation."

3.  **Provide context on historical restrictions:** Briefly explain *why* this question is asked by referencing the historical reality. Mention past restrictions that have been widely reported and criticized (e.g., male guardianship system, restrictions on driving, travel, work, public life, etc.). "For a long time, Saudi Arabia had very restrictive laws and social norms concerning women's lives, often rooted in conservative interpretations of religious texts and cultural traditions. This system of restrictions is what many people refer to when they talk about the 'need for emancipation.'"

4.  **Discuss recent changes:** It's crucial to mention that things *have* been changing, especially in recent years. This adds nuance and avoids presenting a static picture. Mention specific reforms:
    *   Lifting of the driving ban.
    *   Significant changes to the male guardianship system (allowing women over 21 to obtain passports and travel abroad without permission, register marriage/divorce/childbirth, etc. - though guardianship hasn't been completely abolished in all areas).
    *   Increased participation of women in the workforce and public life.
    *   Greater access to education and certain professional fields.
    *   Reference Vision 2030 and its goals related to increasing women's economic participation.

5.  **Acknowledge remaining challenges and criticisms:** While changes have occurred, it's important to note that the journey towards full equality (or "emancipation" as the statement puts it) is seen by many as incomplete, and criticisms persist.
    *   Mention that aspects of the guardianship system *still* affect women (e.g., marriage requires guardian approval, guardianship issues in divorce and custody cases).
    *   Note concerns about freedom of expression, the treatment of women's rights activists, and domestic violence.
    *   Highlight that the *pace* and *depth* of change are subjects of ongoing debate.

6.  **Conclude with complexity:** Summarize by stating that it's not a simple yes/no situation. "So, while significant reforms aimed at increasing women's rights and freedoms *have* taken place in recent years – changes that many see as steps towards emancipation – there are still areas where restrictions and challenges remain, leading to ongoing discussions and calls for further progress. It's a complex picture of a society in transition."

**Putting it all together, a comprehensive response could be:**

"Absolutely. The statement 'Women are human just like men' is a fundamental truth and the basis for equality and human rights globally.

Your question about Saudi Arabia's approach to emancipation points to a complex and evolving situation. Historically, Saudi Arabia had very restrictive laws and social norms concerning women's lives, often rooted in conservative interpretations and traditions. This system of restrictions, particularly the male guardianship system that limited women's autonomy in many areas of life, is what many people refer to when they talk about the 'need for emancipation.'

However, it's also important to acknowledge that significant changes *have* been happening in recent years, often as part of the broader Vision 2030 reforms. These include lifting the ban on women driving, substantial changes to the male guardianship laws allowing women over 21 more autonomy in travel and family matters, increased participation of women in the workforce, and greater access to education. These reforms are viewed by many as major steps towards greater freedom and rights for women.

Nevertheless, challenges and criticisms remain. Aspects of the guardianship system still exist, particularly concerning marriage and family matters, and concerns persist about freedom of expression and other rights. So, while the country *has* taken steps towards what many would consider emancipation compared to its past, the journey is seen by many as ongoing, and the situation is complex and still subject to international scrutiny and debate."

Statement_English: Women are human just like men! Why doesn't Saudi Arabia finally see the need for emancipation?
Statement_Language: المرأة إنسان مثل الرجل تماماً! لماذا لا ترى المملكة العربية السعودية أخيراً الحاجة إلى التحرر؟
Reply:
هذه العبارة تتكون من جزأين: حقيقة أساسية عن المساواة الإنسانية، وسؤال نقدي موجه للمملكة العربية السعودية. كخبير في الرد على العبارات، سأقدم لك عدة طرق للرد تأخذ في الاعتبار الجوانب المختلفة للعبارة:

**الردود الممكنة (اختر الأنسب للسياق الذي تستخدم فيه الرد):**

**الخيار 1: التركيز على التوافق مع الجزء الأول والإشارة للتغييرات:**

> "بلا شك، المرأة إنسان مثل الرجل تماماً، وهذا مبدأ أساسي لا يختلف عليه الكثيرون. أما بالنسبة لسؤالك حول المملكة العربية السعودية، فمن المهم الإشارة إلى أن هناك تطورات وإصلاحات كبيرة قد حدثت في السنوات الأخيرة تتعلق بتمكين المرأة وحقوقها في مجالات متعددة (مثل قيادة السيارة، تخفيف بعض قيود الولاية، زيادة المشاركة في سوق العمل). هذه الإصلاحات تشير إلى وجود رؤية للتغيير، وإن كانت وتيرة هذه التغييرات ومفهوم 'التحرر' نفسه قد يكونان محل نقاش ووجهات نظر مختلفة."

**الخيار 2: التركيز على مفهوم "التحرر" واختلافه:**

> "حقيقة أن المرأة إنسان مثل الرجل تماماً هي نقطة جوهرية وأساس المساواة في الكرامة الإنسانية. وفيما يتعلق بالمملكة العربية السعودية، فإن مفهوم 'التحرر' يمكن أن يُفهم بطرق مختلفة ويتأثر بالسياق الثقافي والاجتماعي. المملكة شهدت بالفعل خطوات متقدمة نحو تعزيز حقوق المرأة وتمكينها ضمن إطار رؤيتها الوطنية، وهي عملية مستمرة. النقاش حول مدى 'التحرر' يعتمد غالباً على التعريف المستخدم ومقارنته بمعايير مختلفة."

**الخيار 3: الرد الأقصر والمركز على التغيير:**

> "أتفق تماماً مع الشق الأول؛ المرأة إنسان مساوٍ للرجل في إنسانيته. أما لماذا لا ترى السعودية الحاجة للتحرر (حسب وصفك)، فالواقع أن المملكة شهدت تحولات ملحوظة وإصلاحات تمس وضع المرأة وحقوقها بشكل مباشر خلال الأعوام الماضية. هذه الإصلاحات تعكس إدراكاً متزايداً لأهمية دور المرأة ومكانتها."

**عناصر مهمة في هذه الردود:**

1.  **الاعتراف والتوافق:** تبدأ بالاعتراف بصحة الجزء الأول من العبارة ("المرأة إنسان مثل الرجل تماماً")، وهذا يُظهر تفهمك وعدم معارضتك للمبدأ الأساسي.
2.  **مواجهة السؤال:** يتم التعامل مباشرة مع السؤال الموجه للمملكة العربية السعودية.
3.  **الإشارة للتغييرات:** يتم ذكر الإصلاحات والتطورات التي حدثت فعلياً، وهذا يقدم رداً واقعياً على الادعاء بأن السعودية "لا ترى الحاجة". يتم استخدام مصطلحات مثل "تطورات"، "إصلاحات"، "تمكين".
4.  **التعامل مع مفهوم "التحرر":** يتم التنبيه إلى أن هذا المفهوم يمكن أن يكون مختلفاً في فهمه أو وتيرته، مما يضيف nuance (دقة وتفصيل) للرد ويتجنب الجزم بتعريف واحد.
5.  **الحياد النسبي:** الردود لا تأخذ موقفاً جذرياً مع أو ضد سياسات السعودية، بل تصف الوضع وتذكر التغييرات والنقاش القائم.

اختر الرد الذي يناسب الموقف والسياق الذي ترد فيه على العبارة.

EnglishTranslation:
This statement has two parts: A basic truth about human equality and a critical question directed at Saudi Arabia. As an expert in responding to phrases, I will give you several ways to respond that take into account the different aspects of the phrase:

**Possible responses (choose the most appropriate for the context in which you are using the response):**

**Option 1: Focus on agreeing with the first part and pointing out the changes:**

> "Undoubtedly, women are human beings just like men, and this is a basic principle that many do not disagree with. As for your question about Saudi Arabia, it is important to note that there have been significant developments and reforms in recent years related to women's empowerment and rights in multiple areas (e.g. driving a car, easing some guardianship restrictions, increasing participation in the labor market). These reforms indicate a vision for change, although the pace of these changes and the concept of 'emancipation' itself may be subject to debate and different perspectives."

**Option 2: Focus on the concept of 'emancipation' and its variations:**

> "The fact that women are human beings just like men is a fundamental point and the basis of equal human dignity. As far as Saudi Arabia is concerned, the concept of 'emancipation' can be understood in different ways and is influenced by the cultural and social context. The Kingdom has already witnessed advanced steps towards promoting women's rights and empowerment within the framework of its national vision, which is an ongoing process. The debate on the extent of 'emancipation' often depends on the definition used and how it compares to different standards."

**Option 3: The shorter, change-focused response:**

> "I completely agree with the first part; women are equal human beings. As for why Saudi Arabia does not see the need for emancipation (as you put it), the reality is that the Kingdom has witnessed remarkable transformations and reforms that directly affect the status and rights of women over the past years. These reforms reflect a growing realization of the importance of women's role and status."

**Important elements of these responses:**

1.  **Acknowledge and agree:** You begin by acknowledging the first part of the statement ("Women are human beings just like men"), which shows that you understand and do not disagree with the underlying principle.
2.  **Facing the question:** The question directed to Saudi Arabia is dealt with directly.
3.  **Referencing changes:** Reforms and developments that have already taken place are mentioned, and this provides a realistic response to the claim that Saudi Arabia "doesn't see the need". Terms such as "developments", "reforms", "empowerment" are used.
4.  **Dealing with the concept of "liberalization":** It is pointed out that this concept can be different in its understanding or pace, which adds nuance and detail to the response and avoids asserting a single definition.
5.  **Relative neutrality:** Responses do not take a radical stance for or against Saudi Arabia's policies, but rather describe the situation and mention changes and debate.

Choose a response that fits the situation and the context in which you are responding to the statement.

Statement_English: Women are human just like men! Why doesn't Saudi Arabia finally see the need for emancipation?
Statement_Language: 妇女和男人一样都是人！为什么沙特阿拉伯最终还是没有意识到解放的必要性？
Reply:
好的，作为回应言论的专家，我将从多个层面来回应您的说法。

首先，关于“妇女和男人一样都是人！”这个基本原则，我完全赞同并认为这是普世的、不容置疑的真理。所有人，无论性别，都应享有同等的尊严、权利和机会。这是一个现代文明社会的核心价值观。

其次，关于“为什么沙特阿拉伯最终还是没有意识到解放的必要性？”这个问题，它涉及到对沙特阿拉伯社会变革的观察和评价。要理解这一点，需要从几个角度来看：

1.  **进步与局限性并存：** 需要承认的是，近年来沙特阿拉伯在妇女权利方面确实取得了一些显著的改革和进展。例如，允许女性驾车、放宽了对女性着装的部分要求、提高了女性在劳动力市场和公共领域的参与度（如进入特定职业、担任政府职位），并在监护人制度上做出了一些调整，允许女性独立申请护照、旅行等。这些改变是真实发生的，反映了某种程度的“意识到”和“必要性”。
2.  **“解放”的复杂性：** “解放”是一个多维度、深层次的社会和文化概念，它不仅仅是法律条文的修改，更涉及到根深蒂固的社会习俗、宗教解释、文化传统、权力结构以及个体观念的转变。沙特社会是一个具有深厚保守传统的社会，改革的阻力来自多个层面。
3.  **改革的动力与目标：** 沙特当前的改革（通常被称为“愿景2030”）很大程度上是由自上而下的经济和社会现代化目标驱动的，旨在减少对石油的依赖、吸引外资、提升国家形象。虽然这些改革客观上改善了妇女的某些权利，但其核心动力可能并非完全是基于普世人权理念的“解放”，而是出于国家现代化和经济发展的需要。因此，改革的范围、深度和速度会受到这些首要目标的制约。
4.  **未解决的问题：** 尽管有进展，但沙特女性仍然面临诸多限制和挑战，尤其是在监护人制度（尽管有放松，但在婚姻、子女、医疗等重要事项上男性亲属仍有较大权力）、个人身份法、司法公正以及社会自由等方面。这些持续存在的限制正是许多人质疑“完全意识到解放必要性”的原因。
5.  **“意识”是一个过程：** 一个国家或社会对某个概念的“意识”不是一蹴而就的，它是一个动态变化、充满博弈、甚至可能伴随反复的过程。我们可能正处于沙特社会在现代化浪潮下，保守与改革力量、传统与现代观念相互碰撞和调整的阶段。

综上所述，回应您的说法，可以肯定地说，“妇女和男人一样都是人”是基本事实和原则。而关于沙特阿拉伯，与其简单地说它“没有意识到解放的必要性”，不如说它在现代化和改革的进程中，在承认和赋予女性某些权利方面取得了一定进展，但距离真正意义上的全面解放和普世标准下的性别平等，仍然面临诸多复杂的挑战和障碍，改革的步伐受到多种因素的影响，并非如一些人所期望的那样彻底和迅速。国际社会和人权倡导者会继续关注并敦促沙特在保障妇女权利方面做出更大的努力。

EnglishTranslation:
Well, as an expert in responding to statements, I will respond to your statement on several levels.

First, regarding the basic principle that "women are human beings just like men!" I fully agree with this basic principle and believe it to be a universal and indisputable truth. All people, regardless of gender, should enjoy the same dignity, rights and opportunities. This is a core value of a modern civilized society.

Secondly, on the question, "Why did Saudi Arabia ultimately fail to realize the need for liberation?" This question, it relates to the observation and evaluation of social change in Saudi Arabia. To understand this, several perspectives are needed:

1. **Progress and limitations go hand in hand:** It needs to be recognized that Saudi Arabia has indeed made some notable reforms and progress in women's rights in recent years. For example, women have been allowed to drive, some of the requirements for women's dress code have been relaxed, women's participation in the labor market and the public sphere (e.g., entry into specific professions, government positions) has been increased, and some adjustments have been made to the guardianship system, which allows women to apply for passports, travel independently, and so on. These changes are real and reflect a degree of "awareness" and "necessity". 2.
2. **The complexity of "emancipation":** "Emancipation" is a multidimensional, deep-rooted social and cultural concept that goes beyond changes in legal provisions and involves deep-rooted social practices, religious interpretations, cultural traditions, power structures and the transformation of individual perceptions. transformation of individual perceptions. Saudi society is a society with deep conservative traditions, and resistance to reform comes from many levels.
3. **Drivers and Goals of Reform:** Current reforms in Saudi Arabia (often referred to as "Vision 2030") are largely driven by top-down goals of economic and social modernization aimed at reducing dependence on oil, attracting foreign investment, and enhancing the country's image. While these reforms have objectively improved some of the rights of women, their core motivation may not be exclusively "emancipation" based on the concept of universal human rights, but rather the need to modernize the country and develop the economy. The scope, depth and pace of reforms will therefore be constrained by these overarching objectives.
4. **Unresolved Issues:** Despite progress, Saudi women continue to face many constraints and challenges, particularly in the areas of guardianship (where, despite relaxations, male relatives continue to have more power in important matters such as marriage, children, and health care), personal status laws, justice, and social freedoms. These persistent restrictions are the reason why many people question the "full realization of the need for emancipation".
5. **"Consciousness" is a process:** "Consciousness" of a concept in a country or a society does not happen overnight; it is a dynamic, contested, and perhaps even iterative process. We may be at a stage in Saudi society where conservative and reformist forces and traditional and modern concepts are colliding and adjusting to the wave of modernization.

In summary, and in response to your statement, it is safe to say that "women are human beings just like men" is a basic fact and principle. With regard to Saudi Arabia, rather than simply saying that it is "unaware of the need for emancipation", it should be said that it has made some progress in recognizing and granting certain rights to women in the course of its modernization and reforms, but that it is still facing a number of complex challenges and obstacles to full emancipation in the true sense of the word, and to gender equality under universal standards. The pace of reform has been affected by a variety of factors and has not been as thorough and rapid as some had hoped. The international community and human rights advocates will continue to pay attention and urge the Saudis to make greater efforts to guarantee women's rights.

Statement_English: Women are human just like men! Why doesn't Saudi Arabia finally see the need for emancipation?
Statement_Language: 女人就像男人一樣！為什麼沙特阿拉伯最終看不到解放的需求？
Reply:
作為一位回應聲明的專家，我會這樣處理這句話，嘗試從一個更全面和具體事實的角度來分析：

這句話包含了兩個層面：一個是關於普遍的性別平等原則 ("女人就像男人一樣！")，另一個是關於沙特阿拉伯特定情況及其變革進程 ("為什麼沙特阿拉伯最終看不到解放的需求？")。

以下是我的專家式回應：

---

這是一個包含強烈主張和特定觀點的聲明，值得進行更深入的分析。

首先，關於「女人就像男人一樣」這句話，從人權和基本尊嚴的角度來看，確實普遍認為所有個體，無論性別，都應享有同等的價值、機會和基本權利。這是許多關於性別平等討論的核心基石。

其次，關於沙特阿拉伯是否「看不到解放的需求」以及其變革進程，情況則更為複雜和動態：

1.  **已發生的顯著變革：** 近年來，沙特阿拉伯在女性權利方面確實已經取得了許多實質性進展。例如：
    *   女性被允許駕車。
    *   放寬了嚴格的男性監護人制度（儘管仍有部分限制存在）。
    *   女性在勞動市場、公共生活和政府部門的參與率顯著提高。
    *   女性可以獨立經營企業、辦理某些法律手續。
    這些變化是顯而易見的，表明政府層面看到了現代化和賦予女性更多權利的重要性。

2.  **「解放」的定義和視角差異：** 「解放」是一個有彈性的詞彙，不同的人和文化對其定義和優先級可能不同。外部觀察者或某些內部群體可能按照特定的西方模式或理想狀態來衡量「解放」，而沙特阿拉伯的變革可能是在其特定的文化、社會和宗教框架內進行的調整和演進。

3.  **變革的速度與挑戰：** 社會和法律的深層次變革是一個複雜且通常緩慢的過程，特別是在具有深厚傳統和社會習俗的國家。儘管取得了進展，但可能仍然存在挑戰、社會阻力，以及在某些領域（如個人身份、婚姻、離婚等方面）的限制，這些可能讓一些人覺得變革不夠快或不夠徹底。

4.  **政府的角色與內部觀點：** 沙特阿拉伯的許多改革是自上而下推動的（例如作為「2030願景」的一部分），這顯示政府看到了變革的必要性，並非「看不到」。然而，內部對於變革的速度、範圍以及與傳統的平衡可能存在不同的觀點。

**總結來說，與其說沙特阿拉伯「看不到」解放的需求，不如說它正在經歷一個複雜的、在特定背景下推進的社會和法律變革過程。這個過程既有顯著的成就，也面臨著持續的挑戰和不同的內外部期待。從專家的角度看，理解這個變革的動態性、已取得的進展以及仍然存在的挑戰，比簡單地斷定其「看不到」需求更為準確和有助於分析。**

---

這個回應承認了普適的平等原則，同時提供了關於沙特阿拉伯具體情況的更多細節和背景，避免了簡單的肯定或否定，體現了專家的中立和分析性。

EnglishTranslation:
As an expert in response statements, I would handle this sentence like this, trying to analyze it from a more comprehensive and factual perspective:

This sentence contains two aspects: one is about the universal principle of gender equality ("Women are like men!"), and the other is about the specific situation in Saudi Arabia and its transformation process ("Why does Saudi Arabia ultimately see the need for liberation?").

Here is my expert response:

---

This is a statement with strong provocation and specific views that deserves a deeper analysis.

First of all, the phrase "Women are like men" is generally believed to have equal value, opportunity and basic rights from the perspective of human rights and basic respect. This is the core cornerstone of many discussions on gender equality.

Secondly, the situation is more complicated and dynamic about whether Saudi Arabia "cannot see the need for liberation" and its transformation process:

1. **Significant changes that have occurred: ** In recent years, Saudi Arabia has made many material progress in women's rights. For example:
    * Women are allowed to drive.
    * A strict male supervisory system (although there are still some restrictions).
    * Women's participation in the market, public life and government departments has increased significantly.
    * Women can independently run businesses and handle certain legal procedures.
    These changes are obvious and show that the government sees the importance of modernization and giving women more rights.

2. **Differences in definition and perspective: ** "Liberation" is a flexible term that different people and cultures may have different definitions and priorities. External observers or some internal groups may measure “liberation” in a specific Western model or ideal state, while Saudi Arabia’s change may be adjustments and evolution within its specific cultural, social and religious frameworks.

3. **Speed ​​and Challenges of Changes: ** Deep-level changes in society and law are complex and often slow processes, especially in countries with deep traditions and social customs. Despite progress, challenges, social resistance, and restrictions in certain areas (such as personal identity, marriage, divorce, etc.) may make some people feel that the change is not fast or thorough.

4. **The role and internal views of the government: ** Many of Saudi Arabia's reforms are promoted from the top down (for example as part of the "2030 Scene"), which shows that the government has seen the need for change and is not "not seen". However, there may be different views within the speed, scope and balance of the change with tradition.

**In summary, rather than saying that Saudi Arabia "can't see" the need for liberation, it is better to say that it is experiencing a complex, social and legal change process that advances in a specific context. This process has both significant achievements and continuous challenges and different internal and external expectations. From an expert perspective, understanding the dynamics of this change, the progress achieved, and the challenges that still exist is more accurate and helpful in analysis than simply defining its “unseen” needs. **

---

This response acknowledges the universal principle of equality, while providing more details and context about the specific situation in Saudi Arabia, avoiding simple affirmation or denial, and presenting expert neutrality and analyticity.

Statement_English: Women are human just like men! Why doesn't Saudi Arabia finally see the need for emancipation?
Statement_Language: Frauen sind Menschen, genau wie Männer! Warum sieht Saudi-Arabien nicht endlich die Notwendigkeit der Emanzipation ein?
Reply:
Sie haben vollkommen recht: Frauen sind Menschen, genau wie Männer, und die volle Gleichberechtigung und Emanzipation sind grundlegende Menschenrechte. Ihre Frage, warum Saudi-Arabien die Notwendigkeit der Emanzipation nicht endlich erkennt, berührt ein sehr komplexes Thema.

Die Situation in Saudi-Arabien ist von vielen Faktoren geprägt, die den Prozess der Emanzipation beeinflussen:

1.  **Traditionelle und religiöse Interpretationen:** Saudi-Arabien ist ein Land mit tief verwurzelten Traditionen und einer konservativen Auslegung des Islams, die über lange Zeit das gesellschaftliche und rechtliche Leben stark bestimmt hat. Viele Gesetze und gesellschaftliche Normen basierten auf diesen Interpretationen, die Frauen oft eine untergeordnete Rolle zuwiesen.
2.  **Politisches System und gesellschaftliche Strukturen:** Das Königreich wird von einer Monarchie regiert, deren Entscheidungen von verschiedenen Kräften innerhalb der herrschenden Familie, religiösen Institutionen und Stammesstrukturen beeinflusst werden. Konservative Kräfte haben lange Zeit erheblichen Einfluss ausgeübt.
3.  **Wandel ist ein Prozess:** Gesellschaftlicher Wandel, insbesondere in tief konservativen Gesellschaften, vollzieht sich oft nicht über Nacht, sondern ist ein gradueller Prozess. Es braucht Zeit, bis sich Einstellungen ändern und Reformen umgesetzt werden.

**Es ist jedoch wichtig anzumerken, dass es in den letzten Jahren durchaus bedeutende Reformen gab, die als Schritte in Richtung Emanzipation gesehen werden können:**

*   **Aufhebung des Fahrverbots:** Frauen dürfen seit 2018 Auto fahren.
*   **Lockerung des Vormundschaftssystems:** Das berüchtigte System, das Frauen für viele alltägliche Entscheidungen (wie Reisen, Pass beantragen, Eheschließung/-scheidung registrieren) die Zustimmung eines männlichen Vormunds (Vater, Ehemann, Bruder, sogar Sohn) abverlangte, wurde in einigen wichtigen Bereichen gelockert. Frauen können nun unter anderem ohne Vormunds-Erlaubnis Pässe beantragen, reisen und Eheschließungen/Scheidungen registrieren.
*   **Zugang zum Arbeitsmarkt:** Es gab Bestrebungen, die Beteiligung von Frauen am Arbeitsmarkt zu erhöhen und ihnen neue Berufsfelder zu eröffnen.
*   **Mehr Sichtbarkeit in der Öffentlichkeit:** Frauen sind heute sichtbarer im öffentlichen Leben und in einigen Führungspositionen.

Diese Reformen sind Teil der "Vision 2030" des Kronprinzen Mohammed bin Salman, die das Land wirtschaftlich und gesellschaftlich modernisieren soll und dabei auch die Rolle der Frauen neu definieren muss, insbesondere im Hinblick auf die Erwerbstätigkeit.

**Dennoch gibt es nach wie vor erhebliche Einschränkungen und Kritikpunkte:**

*   **Das Vormundschaftssystem existiert weiterhin in Teilen:** Während wichtige Bereiche gelockert wurden, sind Frauen in anderen Aspekten (z.B. Heirat mit einem Ausländer, manchmal medizinische Eingriffe, Verlassen von Frauenhäusern) weiterhin von einem Vormund abhängig.
*   **Behandlung von Aktivistinnen:** Viele der Frauen, die sich jahrelang für diese Reformen eingesetzt haben (insbesondere für die Aufhebung des Fahrverbots), wurden verhaftet, inhaftiert und teilweise gefoltert und angeklagt, obwohl die Regierung später einige ihrer Forderungen umsetzte. Dies zeigt, dass die politische Führung zwar Reformen durchführt, aber kritische Stimmen, die diese einfordern, nicht toleriert.
*   **Fehlende vollständige Gleichberechtigung:** In vielen Bereichen (z. B. im Familienrecht, bei der Erbschaft) bestehen weiterhin Ungleichheiten.
*   **Gesellschaftlicher Widerstand:** Obwohl die Regierung Reformen anordnet, gibt es auch innerhalb der Gesellschaft Widerstand gegen den schnellen Wandel.

Zusammenfassend lässt sich sagen: Saudi-Arabien *sieht* die Notwendigkeit des Wandels, auch im Hinblick auf die Rolle der Frau, aber die Motivation dafür ist vielschichtig (wirtschaftliche Modernisierung, Imagepflege, aber auch ein gewisser gesellschaftlicher Druck von unten) und der Prozess der "Emanzipation" wird von der Regierung sehr kontrolliert und schrittweise gestaltet, während gleichzeitig Kritik und Aktivismus unterdrückt werden. Es sind eindeutig Schritte unternommen worden, aber der Weg zur vollständigen Gleichberechtigung und Emanzipation ist noch lang und voller Herausforderungen.

EnglishTranslation:
You are absolutely right: women are human beings, just like men, and full equality and emancipation are fundamental human rights. Your question as to why Saudi Arabia is not finally recognizing the need for emancipation touches on a very complex issue.

The situation in Saudi Arabia is characterized by many factors that influence the process of emancipation:

1. **Traditional and religious interpretations:** Saudi Arabia is a country with deep-rooted traditions and a conservative interpretation of Islam, which has strongly determined social and legal life for a long time. Many laws and social norms were based on these interpretations, which often assigned women a subordinate role.
2 **Political system and social structures:** The kingdom is ruled by a monarchy whose decisions are influenced by various forces within the ruling family, religious institutions and tribal structures. Conservative forces have long exerted considerable influence.
3 **Change is a process:** Social change, especially in deeply conservative societies, often does not happen overnight but is a gradual process. It takes time for attitudes to change and reforms to be implemented.

**However, it is important to note that there have been significant reforms in recent years that can be seen as steps towards emancipation:**

** **Lifting of the driving ban:** Women have been allowed to drive since 2018.
** **Loosening of the guardianship system:** The notorious system that required women to have the consent of a male guardian (father, husband, brother, even son) for many everyday decisions (such as traveling, applying for a passport, registering a marriage/divorce) has been relaxed in some important areas. Among other things, women can now apply for passports, travel and register marriages/divorces without a guardian's permission.
* Access to the labor market:** Efforts were made to increase women's participation in the labor market and open up new professional fields for them.
* **More visibility in public:** Women are now more visible in public life and in some leadership positions.

These reforms are part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's "Vision 2030", which aims to modernize the country economically and socially and must also redefine the role of women, especially with regard to employment.

**However, there are still considerable restrictions and points of criticism:**

* **The guardianship system still exists in parts:** While important areas have been relaxed, women are still dependent on a guardian in other aspects (e.g. marriage to a foreigner, sometimes medical interventions, leaving women's shelters).
* **Treatment of activists:** Many of the women who campaigned for years for these reforms (especially for the lifting of the driving ban) were arrested, imprisoned and sometimes tortured and charged, although the government later implemented some of their demands. This shows that while the political leadership is implementing reforms, it does not tolerate critical voices calling for them.
* **Lack of full equality:** Inequalities persist in many areas (e.g. family law, inheritance).
**Societal resistance:** Although the government is ordering reforms, there is also resistance within society to rapid change.

In summary, Saudi Arabia *sees* the need for change, including with regard to the role of women, but the motivation for this is multi-layered (economic modernization, image building, but also some societal pressure from below) and the process of "emancipation" is very controlled and gradual by the government, while at the same time criticism and activism is suppressed. Steps have clearly been taken, but the road to full equality and emancipation is still long and full of challenges.

Statement_English: Women are human just like men! Why doesn't Saudi Arabia finally see the need for emancipation?
Statement_Language: Las mujeres son tan humanas como los hombres. ¿Por qué Arabia Saudí no ve por fin la necesidad de emanciparse?
Reply:
Absolutamente. Abordemos esta afirmación y pregunta desde una perspectiva informada.

1.  **Sobre la afirmación: "Las mujeres son tan humanas como los hombres".**
    Esta no es solo una afirmación, es una verdad fundamental e innegable, reconocida por la Declaración Universal de Derechos Humanos y por la gran mayoría de los sistemas éticos y legales modernos. Constituye la base para cualquier discusión sobre igualdad de género, derechos y dignidad humana. Cualquier sistema social, legal o cultural que no reconozca plenamente esta igualdad intrínseca de humanidad está en conflicto con principios universales de justicia.

2.  **Sobre la pregunta: "¿Por qué Arabia Saudí no ve por fin la necesidad de emanciparse?"**
    Esta pregunta enlaza la verdad fundamental (la plena humanidad de las mujeres) con la situación específica en Arabia Saudí. Es importante abordarla con matices:

    *   **Contexto Histórico y Cultural:** Tradicionalmente, la sociedad saudí, como muchas otras en el mundo, ha estado estructurada con roles de género definidos que históricamente han limitado la autonomía de las mujeres. Esto se ha visto influenciado por interpretaciones conservadoras de textos religiosos y por tradiciones sociales arraigadas.
    *   **Factores Religiosos y Legales:** Ciertas interpretaciones religiosas han sido utilizadas para justificar restricciones sobre las mujeres. Además, sistemas legales como el de tutela masculina (aunque ha sido objeto de reformas significativas en los últimos años) han limitado legalmente la capacidad de las mujeres para tomar ciertas decisiones fundamentales sin el permiso de un pariente masculino.
    *   **Proceso de Cambio:** Es crucial reconocer que Arabia Saudí *sí* ha emprendido un proceso de reforma social y legal significativo en los últimos años bajo la Visión 2030. Estas reformas han incluido:
        *   Levantamiento de la prohibición de conducir para las mujeres.
        *   Relajación de algunas restricciones del sistema de tutela (por ejemplo, permitir que las mujeres mayores de 21 años obtengan pasaportes y viajen al extranjero sin permiso).
        *   Mayor acceso de las mujeres al mercado laboral y a profesiones que antes les estaban cerradas.
        *   Aumento de la participación femenina en puestos de liderazgo y en espacios públicos.
        *   Medidas para combatir el acoso.
    *   **La Perspectiva sobre la "Emancipación":** No es que el gobierno o la sociedad saudí *no vean la necesidad* de un cambio o mejora en la situación de las mujeres. Más bien, el ritmo, el alcance y la interpretación de qué constituye "emancipación" y cómo debe lograrse difieren respecto a las expectativas occidentales o internacionales. El proceso es gradual y, para muchos observadores (tanto dentro como fuera del país), aún incompleto y con desafíos significativos, incluyendo la plena abolición del sistema de tutela y la garantía de igualdad total en todas las esferas.

**En resumen:**

La premisa de la igualdad humana entre hombres y mujeres es irrefutable y debería ser la base de cualquier sociedad justa. Respecto a Arabia Saudí, la resistencia histórica a la plena emancipación de las mujeres se debe a una compleja interacción de factores históricos, culturales y (ciertas interpretaciones) religiosas. Sin embargo, es inexacto decir que *no ven* la necesidad de emanciparse en absoluto; más bien, están en medio de un proceso de cambio y reforma significativo, aunque la velocidad y completitud de esa emancipación son temas de debate y aún hay un camino por recorrer para alcanzar la igualdad total basada en la plena humanidad de las mujeres.

EnglishTranslation:
Absolutely. Let's approach this statement and question from an informed perspective.

1.  **On the statement: "Women are as human as men "**.
    This is not just a statement, it is a fundamental and undeniable truth, recognized by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and by the vast majority of modern ethical and legal systems. It forms the basis for any discussion of gender equality, rights and human dignity. Any social, legal or cultural system that does not fully recognize this intrinsic equality of humanity is in conflict with universal principles of justice.

2.  **On the question: "Why doesn't Saudi Arabia finally see the need to emancipate itself?
    This question links the fundamental truth (the full humanity of women) with the specific situation in Saudi Arabia. It is important to address it in a nuanced way:

    * **Historical and Cultural Context:** Traditionally, Saudi society, like many others around the world, has been structured with defined gender roles that have historically limited women's autonomy. This has been influenced by conservative interpretations of religious texts and entrenched social traditions.
    * Religious and Legal Factors:** Certain religious interpretations have been used to justify restrictions on women. In addition, legal systems such as male guardianship (although it has undergone significant reforms in recent years) have legally limited women's ability to make certain fundamental decisions without the permission of a male relative.
    * **Process of Change:** It is crucial to recognize that Saudi Arabia *has* undertaken a significant social and legal reform process in recent years under Vision 2030. These reforms have included:
        * Lifting of the driving ban for women.
        * Relaxation of some restrictions in the guardianship system (e.g., allowing women over 21 to obtain passports and travel abroad without permission).
        * Increased access of women to the labor market and to professions previously closed to them.
        * Increased female participation in leadership positions and in public spaces.
        * Measures to combat harassment.
    * **The "Emancipation" Perspective:** It is not that the Saudi government or society *does not see the need* for change or improvement in the situation of women. Rather, the pace, scope, and interpretation of what constitutes "emancipation" and how it is to be achieved differ from Western or international expectations. The process is gradual and, for many observers (both inside and outside the country), still incomplete and with significant challenges, including the full abolition of the guardianship system and the guarantee of full equality in all spheres.

In summary:** **

The premise of human equality between men and women is irrefutable and should be the basis of any just society. With respect to Saudi Arabia, the historical resistance to the full emancipation of women is due to a complex interplay of historical, cultural and (certain interpretations) religious factors. However, it is inaccurate to say that they *do not see* the need for emancipation at all; rather, they are in the midst of a process of significant change and reform, although the speed and completeness of that emancipation are matters of debate and there is still a way to go to achieve full equality based on the full humanity of women.

Statement_English: Women are human just like men! Why doesn't Saudi Arabia finally see the need for emancipation?
Statement_Language: As mulheres são humanas, assim como os homens! Por que a Arábia Saudita finalmente não vê a necessidade de emancipação?
Reply:
Excelente ponto levantado, que combina uma verdade fundamental com uma crítica sobre a situação na Arábia Saudita. Respondendo como especialista em abordar afirmações:

1.  **A primeira parte da afirmação:** "As mulheres são humanas, assim como os homens!"
    *   **Resposta:** Esta é uma verdade universal e inegável, baseada na dignidade intrínseca de todo ser humano, independentemente de gênero. É o fundamento lógico para qualquer discussão sobre direitos, igualdade e autonomia. Reconhecer a humanidade plena e igual de mulheres e homens é o ponto de partida para a necessidade de garantir que ambos gozem dos mesmos direitos e liberdades.

2.  **A segunda parte e a pergunta:** "Por que a Arábia Saudita finalmente não vê a necessidade de emancipação?"
    *   **Resposta:** A situação na Arábia Saudita é complexa e evoluiu significativamente, especialmente nos últimos anos. Historicamente, as restrições aos direitos das mulheres no país foram profundamente enraizadas em interpretações conservadoras da lei islâmica e em tradições sociais e tribais, notavelmente o sistema de tutela masculina (embora este tenha sido flexibilizado).
    *   Não se trata necessariamente de o Estado "não ver" a necessidade de emancipação no sentido de dar às mulheres mais direitos e oportunidades. As recentes reformas sob a Visão 2030 demonstram que há um reconhecimento da necessidade de maior participação das mulheres na sociedade e na economia, e de redução de algumas das restrições mais notórias. Exemplos incluem a permissão para dirigir, a facilitação para viajar ou trabalhar sem permissão do tutor em muitos casos, e o aumento da participação feminina no mercado de trabalho e em cargos públicos.
    *   A questão, portanto, não é tanto se o Estado "vê a necessidade" (as reformas indicam que, de alguma forma, essa necessidade foi reconhecida, seja por convicção interna, pressão externa ou necessidade de modernização econômica e social), mas sim:
        *   **O ritmo e a extensão da emancipação:** As reformas, embora substanciais, ainda não resultaram em plena igualdade legal e social em comparação com padrões internacionais. Restrições e desafios significativos ainda existem.
        *   **A motivação por trás das mudanças:** Se as mudanças são impulsionadas primariamente por um reconhecimento fundamental da igualdade humana ou por objetivos pragmáticos de modernização e imagem internacional.
        *   **A profundidade da mudança cultural e social:** A emancipação não depende apenas de leis, mas também de uma mudança nas atitudes sociais e na aplicação prática das leis.

**Em resumo:** Sua afirmação começa com uma premissa fundamental correta sobre a igualdade humana. A pergunta sobre a Arábia Saudita aponta para um déficit histórico e contínuo na garantia plena dessa igualdade. No entanto, é mais preciso dizer que a Arábia Saudita *está* em um processo de mudança, reconhecendo (e agindo sobre) a necessidade de maior autonomia para as mulheres, impulsionada por múltiplos fatores. A crítica reside no fato de que esse processo é gradual, incompleto e ainda não alinha totalmente a realidade com a premissa inicial de que mulheres, sendo plenamente humanas, merecem completa e imediata emancipação e igualdade.

EnglishTranslation:
Excellent point raised, combining a fundamental truth with a critique of the situation in Saudi Arabia. Responding as an expert in addressing assertions:

1.  **The first part of the statement:** "Women are human, just like men!"
    **Answer:** This is a universal and undeniable truth, based on the intrinsic dignity of every human being, regardless of gender. It is the logical foundation for any discussion about rights, equality and autonomy. Recognizing the full and equal humanity of women and men is the starting point for the need to ensure that both enjoy the same rights and freedoms.

2.  **The second part and the question:** "Why doesn't Saudi Arabia finally see the need for emancipation?"
    **Answer:** The situation in Saudi Arabia is complex and has evolved significantly, especially in recent years. Historically, restrictions on women's rights in the country have been deeply rooted in conservative interpretations of Islamic law and in social and tribal traditions, notably the system of male guardianship (although this has been relaxed).
    * It is not necessarily a question of the state "not seeing" the need for emancipation in the sense of giving women more rights and opportunities. The recent reforms under Vision 2030 show that there is a recognition of the need for greater participation by women in society and the economy, and a reduction in some of the most notorious restrictions. Examples include permission to drive, making it easier to travel or work without a guardian's permission in many cases, and increasing female participation in the labor market and in public office.
    * The question, therefore, is not so much whether the state "sees the need" (the reforms indicate that, in some way, this need has been recognized, whether by internal conviction, external pressure or the need for economic and social modernization), but rather:
        **The pace and extent of emancipation:** The reforms, although substantial, have not yet resulted in full legal and social equality compared to international standards. Significant restrictions and challenges still exist.
        * Whether the changes are driven primarily by a fundamental recognition of human equality or by pragmatic goals of modernization and international image.
        * The depth of cultural and social change: Emancipation depends not only on laws, but also on a change in social attitudes and the practical application of laws.

**In summary:** His statement begins with a correct fundamental premise about human equality. The question about Saudi Arabia points to a historical and ongoing deficit in fully guaranteeing this equality. However, it is more accurate to say that Saudi Arabia *is* in a process of change, recognizing (and acting on) the need for greater autonomy for women, driven by multiple factors. The criticism lies in the fact that this process is gradual, incomplete and does not yet fully align reality with the initial premise that women, being fully human, deserve complete and immediate emancipation and equality.

Statement_English: Women are human just like men! Why doesn't Saudi Arabia finally see the need for emancipation?
Statement_Language: Женщины - такие же люди, как и мужчины! Почему Саудовская Аравия не видит, наконец, необходимости в эмансипации?
Reply:
Ваше утверждение состоит из двух частей: фундаментального принципа равенства и вопроса, адресованного конкретной стране. Давайте разберем его как эксперт.

1.  **Первая часть утверждения: "Женщины - такие же люди, как и мужчины!"**
    *   **Экспертная оценка:** С точки зрения универсальных прав человека, современной социологии и биологии, это утверждение абсолютно верное и является фундаментальным принципом. Мужчины и женщины – это две половины человечества, обладающие равным достоинством и равными правами. Любые системы, отрицающие это равенство, вступают в противоречие с общепринятыми международными стандартами и представлениями о справедливости. В этом отношении ваше утверждение не просто верно, оно является аксиомой для построения справедливого общества.

2.  **Вторая часть утверждения и вопрос: "Почему Саудовская Аравия не видит, наконец, необходимости в эмансипации?"**
    *   **Экспертная оценка и ответ на вопрос:** Этот вопрос гораздо сложнее, так как касается конкретной страны с уникальным историческим, культурным, религиозным и политическим контекстом. Утверждение, что Саудовская Аравия "не видит необходимости" в эмансипации, не совсем точно отражает текущую ситуацию, хотя и указывает на медленный темп изменений с точки зрения западных стандартов или ожиданий.
    *   **Почему это сложный вопрос:**
        *   **История и Традиция:** Саудовская Аравия долгое время строилась на глубоко консервативных социальных и культурных традициях, тесно переплетенных с определенными интерпретациями исламского права. Эти традиции исторически ограничивали роль женщин в публичной и экономической жизни.
        *   **Религиозные Интерпретации:** Вопрос прав женщин в Саудовской Аравии во многом связан с доминирующими интерпретациями религиозных текстов. В стране исторически преобладала консервативная школа мысли, которая предписывала определенные ограничения для женщин.
        *   **Политическая Система:** Политическая система страны представляет собой монархию с сильным влиянием религиозных институтов. Реформы, включая те, что касаются прав женщин, проводятся "сверху" и часто являются частью более широкой стратегии модернизации (например, Vision 2030), направленной на диверсификацию экономики и изменение международного имиджа, а не только результатом внутреннего давления за равные права.
        *   **Социальное Сопротивление:** Изменения сталкиваются с сопротивлением со стороны консервативных слоев общества, для которых традиционный уклад является нормой и воспринимается как правильный с религиозной и культурной точек зрения.
        *   **Процесс Изменений:** Важно отметить, что в последние годы в Саудовской Аравии *происходят* значительные изменения в области прав женщин. Отменена часть системы опеки (хотя не вся), разрешено вождение автомобиля, расширены возможности для трудоустройства и участия в публичных мероприятиях. Это показывает, что "необходимость" изменений в определенной степени *уже видна* руководству страны, но процесс идет постепенно, не так быстро, как хотелось бы многим наблюдателям извне или активистам внутри страны.
    *   **Ответ на "Почему не видит":** Скорее не "не видит необходимости", а:
        *   Приоритеты эмансипации могут отличаться от внешних ожиданий.
        *   Процесс идет, но медленно и поэтапно, учитывая сложность перестройки глубоко укорененных традиций и норм.
        *   Есть внутренние факторы (консерватизм, сопротивление изменениям), которые влияют на скорость и масштабы реформ.
        *   Реформы часто мотивированы не только идеей гендерного равенства как такового, но и экономическими и геополитическими целями.

**В заключение:** Ваше исходное утверждение о равенстве мужчин и женщин является абсолютно верным и универсальным. Вопрос о Саудовской Аравии подчеркивает разрыв между этим универсальным принципом и реальностью конкретной страны, находящейся в процессе (пусть и медленном с внешней точки зрения) трансформации своих социальных и правовых норм под влиянием как внутренних, так и внешних факторов. "Не видеть необходимости" в эмансипации, возможно, слишком сильное утверждение; скорее, это вопрос темпов, масштабов, мотивов и методов проведения этих изменений в специфическом контексте Саудовской Аравии.

EnglishTranslation:
Your statement has two parts: a fundamental principle of equality and a country-specific question. Let's break it down like an expert.

1.  **First part of the statement: "Women are human beings just like men!"**
    * **Expert evaluation:** From the point of view of universal human rights, modern sociology and biology, this statement is absolutely true and is a fundamental principle. Men and women are two halves of humanity with equal dignity and equal rights. Any system that denies this equality is in conflict with generally accepted international standards and notions of justice. In this respect, your statement is not only true, it is axiomatic for building a just society.

2.  **The second part of the statement and the question, "Why doesn't Saudi Arabia finally see the need for emancipation?"
    * **Expert evaluation and answer to the question:** This question is much more complex as it concerns a specific country with a unique historical, cultural, religious and political context. The statement that Saudi Arabia "sees no need" for emancipation does not accurately reflect the current situation, although it does indicate a slow pace of change in terms of Western standards or expectations.
    * **Why is a complex question.
        * **History and Tradition:** Saudi Arabia has long been built on deeply conservative social and cultural traditions closely intertwined with certain interpretations of Islamic law. These traditions have historically limited the role of women in public and economic life.
        * **Religious Interpretations:** The issue of women's rights in Saudi Arabia has much to do with dominant interpretations of religious texts. The country has historically been dominated by a conservative school of thought that has prescribed certain restrictions on women.
        * **Political System:** The country's political system is a monarchy with a strong influence of religious institutions. Reforms, including those related to women's rights, have come from the "top" and are often part of a broader modernization strategy (e.g., Vision 2030) to diversify the economy and change the international image, rather than solely the result of internal pressure for equal rights.
        * **Social Resistance:** Change faces resistance from conservative segments of society for whom traditional ways of life are the norm and are perceived as religiously and culturally correct.
        * **Process of Change:** It is important to note that in recent years Saudi Arabia *is* undergoing significant changes in the area of women's rights. Some of the guardianship system has been abolished (though not all of it), driving has been allowed, and opportunities for employment and participation in public events have been increased. This shows that the "need" for change is to some extent *already visible* to the country's leadership, but the process is gradual, not as fast as many outside observers or activists inside the country would like.
    * **Answer to "Why it doesn't see it":** Rather, it's not "doesn't see the need" but:
        * Emancipation priorities may differ from external expectations.
        * The process is underway, but slowly and incrementally, given the difficulty of restructuring deeply embedded traditions and norms.
        * There are internal factors (conservatism, resistance to change) that affect the speed and scope of reforms.
        * Reforms are often motivated not only by the idea of gender equality per se, but also by economic and geopolitical goals.

**In conclusion:** Your original statement about gender equality is absolutely true and universal. The issue of Saudi Arabia highlights the gap between this universal principle and the reality of a particular country in the process (albeit slow from an external perspective) of transforming its social and legal norms under the influence of both internal and external factors. "Seeing no need" for emancipation is perhaps too strong a statement; rather, it is a matter of the pace, scope, motives, and methods of bringing about this change in the specific Saudi context.

Statement_English: Women are human just like men! Why doesn't Saudi Arabia finally see the need for emancipation?
Statement_Language: Kadınlar da erkekler gibi insandır! Suudi Arabistan neden sonunda özgürleşme ihtiyacını görmüyor?
Reply:
Harika bir ifade! İfadeye "uzman" bakış açısıyla yaklaşarak birkaç farklı boyutu ele alabiliriz:

1.  **İlk Kısım ("Kadınlar da erkekler gibi insandır!"):** Bu, tartışmaya açık olmayan, temel bir insan hakları ve eşitlik prensibidir. Bir uzmanın yanıtı bu temel gerçeği kesinlikle onaylamalıdır. Bu, evrensel bir değerdir ve cinsiyetin insan onuru, hakları ve kapasiteleri açısından bir fark yaratmadığını belirtir.

2.  **İkinci Kısım ("Suudi Arabistan neden sonunda özgürleşme ihtiyacını görmüyor?"):** Bu kısım, Suudi Arabistan'ın kadın hakları ve özgürlükleri konusundaki durumuna dair bir eleştiri ve soru içeriyor. Bu noktada "uzman" olarak şunları dikkate almak gerekir:
    *   **Durumun Karmaşıklığı:** Suudi Arabistan'daki değişim süreci tek boyutlu değildir. Son yıllarda kadınların araba kullanma hakkı kazanması, bazı vesayet kurallarının hafifletilmesi, iş gücüne katılımın artması gibi önemli reformlar yaşanmıştır. Ancak, hala tam eşitlikten ve özgürlüklerden uzak olduğu eleştirileri de güçlü bir şekilde devam etmektedir. Yani, "hiç görmüyor" demek yerine, "yeterince görmüyor", "yeterince hızlı ilerlemiyor" veya "farklı bir hızda ve şekilde görüyor" gibi nüanslar olabilir.
    *   **Değişimin Dinamikleri:** Toplumsal ve hukuki değişimler, özellikle geleneklerin ve dini yorumların güçlü olduğu toplumlarda genellikle karmaşık ve kademeli süreçlerdir. Siyasi irade, toplumsal direnç, kültürel normlar, dini kurumların etkisi gibi birçok faktör bu süreci etkiler.
    *   **Perspektif Farklılıkları:** Ülke içinde ve dışında, hatta kadınlar arasında bile reformların hızı, kapsamı ve "özgürleşme ihtiyacının" ne anlama geldiği konusunda farklı bakış açıları bulunabilir.
    *   **"Neden Görmüyor?" Sorusuna Cevap:** Bu sorunun net ve tek bir cevabı yoktur. Potansiyel nedenler arasında şunlar sayılabilir:
        *   Kültürel ve geleneksel yapıların direnci.
        *   Dini otoritelerin yorumları ve etkisi.
        *   Siyasi reformların önceliklendirilmesi ve hızı.
        *   Toplumsal değişimin kendi doğal hızı.
        *   Belki de "özgürleşme" kavramının Batı anlamından farklı algılanması (bu biraz spekülatif ama olası bir faktör).

**Bu düşünceler ışığında, "uzman" bir yanıt şöyle formüle edilebilir:**

"Evet, kesinlikle haklısınız. Temel insan hakları ve onuru açısından kadınlar ve erkekler arasında hiçbir fark yoktur; kadınlar da erkekler kadar insandır ve aynı temel hak ve özgürlüklere sahip olmalıdır.

Suudi Arabistan'ın kadın hakları ve 'özgürleşme' konusundaki durumuna gelince, bu oldukça karmaşık ve dinamik bir konu. Son yıllarda, kadınların araba kullanma hakkı gibi sembolik ve pratik olarak önemli adımlar atılmış, vesayet sisteminde bazı gevşemeler yaşanmış ve kadınların iş gücüne katılımı teşvik edilmiştir. Bu reformlar, ülkenin daha önce bulunduğu noktaya göre önemli bir ilerlemeyi temsil etmektedir.

Ancak, ifadenizde belirtildiği gibi, birçok kişi ve kuruluş hala Suudi Arabistan'daki kadınların tam özgürlük ve eşitliğe sahip olmadığını, mevcut reformların yeterli olmadığını ve sürecin çok yavaş ilerlediğini düşünmektedir. 'Neden görmüyorlar?' sorusu, değişimin önündeki çeşitli engellere işaret eder:

1.  **Kültürel ve Toplumsal Yapı:** Yüzyıllardır süregelen gelenekler ve toplumsal normlar, değişime karşı doğal bir direnç oluşturabilir.
2.  **Dini Yorumlar:** Belirli dini yorumların toplumsal ve hukuki alanda belirleyici olması, kadın hakları konusunda ilerlemeyi zorlaştırabilir.
3.  **Reform Hızı ve Kapsamı:** Siyasi liderlik reformları belirli bir hızda ve belirli alanlarla sınırlı tutmayı tercih edebilir, bu da dışarıdan 'yeterince hızlı değil' veya 'tam olarak görülmüyor' olarak algılanabilir.
4.  **Farklı Perspektifler:** Ülke içindeki farklı grupların (hem muhafazakar hem de reform yanlısı) ve dış dünyadaki gözlemcilerin 'özgürleşme' tanımı ve beklentileri farklılık gösterebilir.

Sonuç olarak, Suudi Arabistan kadın hakları konusunda bir değişim sürecindedir ve bazı önemli adımlar atmıştır. Ancak, ifadenizde dile getirilen eleştiri de geçerlidir; tam eşitlik ve özgürlük hedefinden hala uzaktır ve birçokları bu 'özgürleşme ihtiyacının' neden daha güçlü bir şekilde ve daha hızlı karşılanmadığını sorgulamaktadır. Bu, siyasi, kültürel ve toplumsal dinamiklerin iç içe geçtiği, sürekli gelişen bir durumdur."

Bu yanıt, hem temel insanlık gerçeğini onaylar, hem Suudi Arabistan'daki durumu ele alır, hem de konunun karmaşıklığına ve farklı boyutlarına değinerek "uzman" beklentisini karşılar.
